taxonomicNotes:
The species is often confused with Enallagma deserti.

Up until 2005, Enallagma cyathigerum was thought to be a single species with a circumpolar distribution. However, Turgeon et al. (2005) demonstrated that the Nearctic and Palearctic populations were really two species: E. cyathigerum (occurring in the Palearctic) and E. annexum (occurring in the Nearctic).

The Japanese species Sympetrum frequens (Selys, 1883) was considered as the insular vicariant of S. depressiusculum (Selys, 1841). Recent phylogenetic analyses showed that both taxa pertain to a single species. Therefore Sympetrum frequens is treated a junior synonym of S. depressisuculum (Sawabe et al. 2004).
species known both sexes, illustrated.
The Large Copper has several subspecies in Europe.
According to the World Spider Catalog Macrothele should be placed in its own family the Macrothelidae.

Subfamily Potaminae. Pretzmann (1983) recognised five subpopulations for this species (as Potamon (Telphusa) fluviatilis fluviatilis, which he called nations), mainly for populations that inhabit islands in the Aegean and Mediterranean. The subspecies Potamon fluviatile lanfrancoi Capolongo and Cilia, 1990 was also not recognised by Brandis et al. (2000). This species was revised to Potamon (Eutelphusa) fluviatile by Brandis et al. (2000) and is treated here as Potamon fluviatile.

Subfamily Potaminae. Pretzmann (1962, 1983, 1986) recognised four subpopulations for this species (as subspecies and nations), mainly for populations that inhabit islands. This taxon was most recently revised as Potamon (Potamon) rhodium by Brandis et al. (2000) and it is treated here as Potamon rhodium.

Subfamily Potaminae. Pretzmann (1983) recognised three subpopulations for this species (as Potamon (Pontipotamon) ibericum tauricum, which he called nations), mainly for populations that inhabit islands. The subspecies Potamon ibericum meandris Pretzmann, 1963 and Potamon albanicum Starobogatov and Vassilenko (1979) were also not recognised by Brandis et al. (2000). This species was revised to Potamon (Pontipotamon) ibericum by Brandis et al. (2000) and is treated here as Potamon ibericum.

Subfamily Potaminae. Seven subspecies of P. potamios have been recognised over the years (Ghiavarini 1934; Pretzmann 1962, 1984, 1986; Bott 1967) mainly to recognise subpopulations of this species that inhabit islands. This taxon was most recently revised as Potamon (Potamon) potamios by Brandis et al. (2000) and it is treated here as Potamon potamios.

Sub species:
leniusculus (Signal crayfish): Astacus leniusculus was placed on the Official List of Specific Names in Zoology, name number 2244, in Opinion 855 of the International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature. (See Melville, 1968: 84).
klamathensis (Klamath Signal Crayfish)
trowbridgii: (Columbia River Signal Crayfish)

Recent genetic studies (Crandall lab) suggest that these different subspecies are in fact distinct.  Thus the P. klamathensis and P. trowbridgii might themselves be endangered whereas the P. leniusculus is more broad spread and indeed an invasive.
This species has two subspecies; the nominal subspecies from the Greek island Ikaria (Stenopterus similatus similatus), and S. s. mehli Sama, 1995, from the island of Cyprus.

The taxonomic status of this species appears to be unclear due to the varying opinions of different authors. In Spain, this species is currently regarded as a variety of C. pilosus (Gonzáles Peña et al. 2007). Sama (2000) however states this is a separate species and this is supported by Brustel et al. (2002).

The Osmoderma species complex is here treated as five separate species (barnabita, eremita, cristinae, italica and lassallei), following Audisio et al. (2007, 2008). Distribution limits of these different forms remain poorly resolved, but for the purpose of these assessments we follow the approximate distribution limits outlined in Audisio et al. (2007, 2008). There is ongoing debate as to whether or not these forms constitute valid species,  but for the purpose of this assessment we are assessing each form separately.
Recorded from the Atlas Mountains in northern Africa. However, these records are thought to be related to different species (R. ungaricus and R. siculus).
This species was previously placed as Brachypteroma ottomanum Heyden, 1863. However, it is now recognised that the former synonym, Dolocerus reichii Mulsant, 1862 is the pre-existing senior name.
This species has many synonyms and a taxonomic revision is needed.

The Osmoderma species complex is here treated as five separate species (barnabita, eremita, cristinae, italica and lassallei), following Audisio et al. (2007, 2008). Distribution limits of these different forms remain poorly resolved, but for the purpose of these assessments we follow the approximate distribution limits outlined in Audisio et al. (2007, 2008). There is ongoing debate as to whether or not these forms constitute valid species, but for the purpose of this assessment we are assessing each form separately.


According to Lobl and Smetana (2006) O. barnabita is synonym of O. coriarium.

This butterfly (known as P. daplidice for the last 250 years) was recently separated into two species: P. daplidice and P. edusa Fabricius, 1777 (Geiger et al. 1988), but the latter is currently considered to be a subspecies of the former (Porter et al. 1997; Honey and Scoble 2001). Nominotypical daplidice occurs throughout northwest Africa, the Iberian peninsula, Corsica, Sardinia and northwest Europe (occurs occasionally in the UK as an infrequent migrant/vagrant). P. daplidice edusa occurs in northwest France, and Italy eastwards, with a hybrid zone in northwest Italy. The taxa were separated by electrophoretic analysis and cannot be separated with any degree of certainty on external morphology.

A number of subspecies have been defined, but the validity of many of these is uncertain because of the reliance of the species on cryptic colouration and the large amount of variation in this colouration, in response to substrate colouration, between and within subpopulations (W.J. Tennent pers. comm. 2008).
Regarded by some authors as the same species as P. kaehleri (Bense 1995).

Nazari & Sperling (2007) reported significant genetic divergence between populations of this species from Palestine and Turkey, suggesting that there might be more species in this complex than what was previously reported.At present, there are X subspecies recognised: the nominate subspecies apollinus; A. apollinus forsteri Koçak, 1977; A. a. nikodemusi Stüning & Wagener, 1989; A. a. drusicus de Freina & Leestmans, 2003;
The taxonomic status of this taxon and its relationship to C. leander, C. arcania, and C. gardetta are unclear and require further research.
Platycnemis pennipes nitidula may be valid as a separate species, but further genetic work is necessary to confirm this.
There are two subspecies; R. alpina alpina which is relatively widespread from Spain to Turkey and R. alpina syriaca which is a relict subspecies of the southeastern Turkish population.
Astacus astacus is comprised of three subspecies: Astacus astacus astacus, Astacus astacus balcanicus, Astacus astacus colchicus.
Lindenia inkiti described from the south Caucasus area by Bartenef falls in the variability of the species and thus is a synonym of L. tetraphylla.

This small species of Orthetrum is mainly Asian in distribution and is replaced in Africa and southwestern Arabia by its sister taxon Orthetrum kollmannspergeri Buchholz, 1959. According to Dumont and Veschuren (2005) and Clausnitzer and Dijkstra (2005), all African and west-Arabian records of O. taeniolatum should be ascribed to O. kollmannspergeri Buchholz, 1959. Unfortunately the name kollmannspergeri Buchholz, 1959 will fall into synonymy of an earlier available name (Ober in prep.).

In Europe three subspecies could be recoginsed. The subspecies O. f. forcipatus occurs in most of Europe. The subspecies O. f. unguiculatus (Vander Linden, 1823) is confined to Iberia, Italy and the southeastern part of France. The third  subspecies O. f. albotibiualis is in Europe confined to the eastern Mediterranean Greek islands and Cyprus. Genetic studies failed to find any genetic differentiation between these three subspecies (Ferreira et al. 2014).
Coenagrion vanbrinkae Lohmann, 1993 is considerd a junior synonym of C. ornatum (Kosterin and Ahmad 2018).

Several subspecies - Coenagrion pulchellum mediterraneum Schmidt, 1964, C. p. interruptum (Charpentier, 1840) and C. p. saisanicum (Belyshev, 1964), have been described in the past. They were mostly based on variations in melanism and in size. As both characters are highly variable within a given region, these subspecies are no longer recognized as valid.
The subspecies Erythromma viridulum orientale Schmidt, 1960 doesn't differ statistically from many European populations and cannot be validated (Boudot and Jacquemin 1988)

No valid subspecies is known, as P. elisabethae matches the full species rank (Kalkman & Lopau 2006). The populations in Morocco are structurally identical to P. nymphula but genetically closer to P. elisabethae (Guan et al. 2013).

The overall taxonomy of Cordulegaster insignis Schneider, 1845 is much more complex than previously believed. Many local forms of this polytypic species do not fit the so-called "specific" criteria of the populations from the type locality. A recent taxonomical revision of the Cordulegaster of the eastern part of the Western Palearctic using molecular phylogeny and morphological tried to solve the problem (Schneider et al. 2021). They considered Cordulegaster coronata Morton, 1915 (Central Asia) and C. mzymtae Bartenef, 1929 (southern Caucasus and NE Anatolia) as good species and no longer as being part of C. insignis. They further consider C. charpentieri as a good species (southern Caucasus, eastern Turkey and Iran) and proposed C. cilicia as a new species (Anatolia, eastern Turkey and the Levant).  
It is not unlikely that more systematic surveys of southwest Asia might lead to new insights in the taxonomy of the Cordulegaster species present in the area.

Cordulegaster picta is a very variable taxon in colour pattern which shows several morphs. Some populations are very yellow and resemble C. heros or some forms of C. insignis and C. helladica in colour pattern, others are very black and resemble C. bidentata, C. b. boltonii, C. trinacriae or even C. vanbrinkae with respect to their general colour. The black forms seem to be localized in the western Rhodopes mountains between Greece and Bulgaria, in European Turkey and in northern Anatolia. The yellowest forms are known from the Eastern Rhodopes, from some East Aegean islands and from western and southern Anatolia. Intermediate populations are known as well. No subspecific differentiation is possible between these forms, as none show a proper geographic range. Only the examination of the abdominal appendages is needed for a correct identification of this species and all its morphs.

There is some debate over whether Somatochlora meridionalis is a valid species or only a subspecies of S. metallica. In this assessment, both taxa will be treated as full species. Some old records dealing with S. metallica in the Balkans may refer to S. meridionalis.
The family name Euphaeidae should be replaced by the name Epallagidae Needham, 1903 in strict application of the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature

The Asiatic Gomphus ubadschii Schmidt 1953, considered as a subspecies of G. flavipes for a long time, is now placed at the full species rank. The so-called subspecies Gomphus flavipes sibirica Bartenev, 1909 is not different from the European taxon and has not been validated

Gomphus vulgatissimus is rather similar to G. schneiderii and the latter is sometimes considered as a subspecies of the former, with which it can be easily confused. Both taxa either overlap and hybridize or are connected through clinal variation by intermediate forms, so that the geographic limit between them cannot be traced with certainty. Some intermediates have even been described under G. schneideri helladicus Buchholz, 1954. Due to this complexity, information on distribution in parts of the Balkan Peninsula is unclear and genetic studies will be needed to clarify the situation in this area.

The species (as Lestes parvidens) was previously considered a subspecies of Lestes viridis. 

Both L. viridis and L. parvidens were moved to the genus Chalcolestes Kennedy, 1920, based on genetic analysis (Dumont pers. comm. 2007, Schorr and Paulson 2015).

This species is assessed without any subspecies distinction.
Two subspecies are currently recognized, namely Lestes virens virens (Charpentier, 1825) in the west Mediterranean area, and L. virens vestalis Rambur, 1842 in the rest of Europe. Distribution and identification of both subspecies is not clear. The distinction of these two spp. in their contact zone is sometimes not possible (for example in parts of France). The precise identity of the Anatolian member of L. virens is still unclear.
In some literature, this species has been assigned to the genera Platetrum or Ladona (Schmidt 1987) but presently most authors use the Libellula as genus name.

The southwest Asian Libellula pontica was until recently considered to be a subspecies of L. fulva. In some literature, this species has been assigned to the genus Ladona. Here it is assessed as Libellula.

In northern Spain, subspecies ibericum occurs, which requires further taxonomic study. Sympetrum decoloratum, which occurs in Asian Turkey and further east is considered to be a valid species, and not a subspecies of S. vulgatum. In eastern Asia several other subspecies have been described.
The taxon is a member of the H. nivalis group (Dathe 2000).
There are no taxonomic problems known at present.
This species replaces possibly H. communis at its southern and eastern distribution edges (see Dathe 2000). A taxonomic state of subspecies is discussed.
There are no taxonomic problems known at present.
The taxon is a member of the H. nivalis group (Dathe 2000).
This species belongs to a highly diverse taxonomic group, which is not yet fully understood.
The taxon is a member of the Hylaeus nivalis group (Dathe 2000).
This species belongs to a highly diverse taxonomic group, which is not yet fully understood. It is probably a local variant only and is closely related to Hylaeus hyalinatus.
The taxon is a member of the H. nivalis group (Dathe 2000).
The taxonomy of the Hylaeus gibbus group was recently revisited (Straka and Bogusch 2011). A series of problems occurred and the first suggestions to solve them were given.

Taxonomic issues regarding the position of Andrena fimbriata within the Andrena labialis group are treated by Schönitzer et al. (1995).

Warncke (1967) examined the type of this species. Most previous records belong to A. forsterella, A. variabilis or other species of the subgenus Holandrena.

This taxon was considered until recently as a synonym of Habropoda tarsata (e.g., Friese 1896, Brooks 1988). It has been revised as a valid species only very recently by Schwarz and Gusenleitner (2001).

Marinov and Seidenbusch (2007) place this taxon in a new monotypic genus, Corduliochlora. We refrain from using Corduliochlora as long as no overall phylogenetic study of the Corduliidae has been undertaken.

Both Lestes viridis and L. parvidens were moved to the genus Chalcolestes Kennedy, 1920, based on genetic analysis (Dumont pers. comm. 2007, Schorr and Paulson 2015).

Until ten years ago Chalcolestes parvidens was considered a subspecies of Chalcolestes viridis, but there is now a wide consensus that they should be considered separate species.
The species was described in the genus Rhophitoides but it was later moved to Rophites. Review by Pesenko and Astafurova (2006) resulted in epiroticus being moved back to Rhophitoides.
The subspecies Lasioglossum bavaricum olympicum (Warncke, 1982) is found in the mountains of Greece. The nominal subspecies is found throughout the rest of it's distribution.
The subgeneric attribution of Andrena ebmerella is uncertain.

There are three different subspecies that occur in different countries: D. angustissimus angustissimus is found in Turkey, D. angustissimus liviae is found in Rhodes (Greece), and D. angustissimus troodi is found in Cyprus and Lebanon (Löbl and Smetana 2010).
Two subspecies are known: Callimenus macrogaster macrogaster and C. m. longicollis, defined on mostly subtle differences in the female subgenital plate.
Two subspecies occur in the Mediterranean: P. desfontainii ssp., in Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, Libya and Crete (Greece) and P. d. inhumeralis in Greece, Turkey, Jordan, Israel and Syria.
Described in 1993 as one of four species identified within a species complex (with P. budensis, P. caucasicus and other). Delimitation and distributional ranges are not yet clear.

Evidence from a global study of DNA barcodes supports the North American population as part of a species widespread in Europe and Asia (Williams et al. 2012, 2014).

Bombus cryptarum is difficult to identify and has been generally accepted as a valid species only recently. This explains why it has been explicitly dealt with in rather few articles (Rasmont et al. 2014).
This species appears to have two different subspecies; C. gratiosus gratiosus (Syria, Lebanon, Israel) and C. gratiosus sparsus (Turkey).
It was previously described as a subspecies of S. marginatus but it is thought to be a separate species (Bogusch and Straka in prep.).

The current edition of the Catalogue of Palaearctic Coleoptera Volume III (Löbl and Smetana 2006) considers all the genus-group names of Aphodiinae (Dellacasa and Dellacasa 2006) at subgenus rank. In the next edition of the Catalogue in prep., all the subgenera will be raised to genus rank (M. Dellacasa and S. Ziani pers. comm. 2014).

The current edition of the Catalogue of Palaearctic Coleoptera Volume III (Löbl and Smetana 2006) considers all the genus-group names of Aphodiinae (Dellacasa and Dellacasa 2006) at subgenus rank. In the next edition of the Catalogue in prep., all the subgenera will be raised to genus rank (M. Dellacasa and S. Ziani pers. comm. 2014).

The first edition of the Catalogue of Palaearctic Coleoptera Volume III considers all the genus-group names of Aphodiinae (Dellacasa and Dellacasa 2006) at subgenus rank. In the next edition of the Catalogue in prep., all the subgenera will be raised to genus rank (M. Dellacasa and S. Ziani pers. comm. 2014).

The first edition of the Catalogue of Palaearctic Coleoptera Volume III considers all the genus-group names of Aphodiinae (Dellacasa and Dellacasa 2006) at subgenus rank. In the next edition of the Catalogue in prep., all the subgenera will be upgraded to genus rank (M. Dellacasa and S. Ziani pers. comm. 2014).

The current edition of the Catalogue of Palaearctic Coleoptera Volume III (Löbl and Smetana 2006) considers all the genus-group names of Aphodiinae (Dellacasa and Dellacasa 2006) at subgenus rank. In the next edition of the Catalogue in prep., all the subgenera will be raised to genus rank (M. Dellacasa and S. Ziani pers. comm. 2014).

The current edition of the Catalogue of Palaearctic Coleoptera Volume III (Löbl and Smetana 2006) considers all the genus-group names of Aphodiinae (Dellacasa and Dellacasa 2006) at subgenus rank. In the next edition of the Catalogue in prep., all the subgenera will be raised to genus rank (M. Dellacasa and S. Ziani pers. comm. 2014).

The first edition of the Catalogue of Palaearctic Coleptera Volume III (Löbl and Smetana 2006) considers all the genus-group names of Aphodiinae at subgenus rank. In the next edition of the Catalogue to be published in 2015, all the subgenera will be upgraded to genus rank (M. Dellacasa and S. Ziani pers. comm. 2014).

The first edition of the Catalogue of Palaearctic Coleptera Volume III (Löbl and Smetana 2006) considers all the genus-group names of Aphodiinae at subgenus rank. In the next edition of the Catalogue to be published in 2015, all the subgenera will be upgraded to genus rank (M. Dellacasa and S. Ziani pers. comm. 2014).

The first edition of the Catalogue of Palaearctic Coleptera Volume III (Löbl and Smetana 2006) considers all the genus-group names of Aphodiinae at subgenus rank. In the next edition of the Catalogue to be published in 2015, all the subgenera will be upgraded to genus rank (M. Dellacasa and S. Ziani pers. comm. 2014).

The status of the taxon is not yet well defined as sometimes it has been recorded as a subspecies of Bodiloides ictericus (Laicharting, 1781). A thorough study of both taxa from the whole distribution area is needed to define the correct taxonomic level.
The taxonomy of this species is well known (Löbl and Smetana 2006, Nikolajev 2003).
Previously considered as a subspecies of B. bubalus (Oliv). It was separated from B. bubalus by Janssens in 1938.

This species belongs to the ovatus group and this group of species is characterised by similar external morphology. Only the study of laminae of the internal sac of the aedeagus enables the identification of the species. Thus, many old records from the species from the ovatus group could be attributed to the species O. dellacasai.

Onthophagus opacicollis and O. similis are considered close species. The genetic distances between O. opacicollis and O. similis populations as a function of the biogeographic scenery (allopatry vs. sympatry) indicate that these taxa are not completely reproductively isolated across their entire geographic range, thus suggesting a still unfinished speciation process in sympatric areas and a fully realised speciation by means of ecological segregation in allopatry (Pizzo et al. 2013). In Spain, both the existence of some gene flow between O. opacicollis and O. similis in one place (El Barraco, Central Spain) and isolation in others (Sierra Nevada, southeast Spain) was demonstrated. Geographic areas hosting populations of both taxa with intermediate genetic distances (Doñana, southwest Spain) also exist in the Iberian Peninsula (Martín-Piera and Boto 1999). However, a chromosomal analysis showed no evidence of hybridization between O. similis and O. opacicollis where they occur together in central Spain (Angus 2008).
Ammobates melectoides is often understood as a subspecies of A. oraniensis. Taxonomy of this species needs to be studied in detail in the future.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear as the species is only known from the type specimens (C. Praz pers. comm. 2014).
It is not clear if it is a distinct species from M. hungarica (C. Praz pers. comm. 2014).
Due to the recent split of T. taygetica and T. endymion the knowledge on the distribution of each species is limited to the specimens which have so far been examined (Coutsis 2005).
Real´s Wood White has recently been separated from the Wood White (L. sinapis). However, in the field the species cannot be distinguished from each other.

The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain. For long it was considered a subspecies of E. variegatus but recently it has been elevated to a separate species. However, its true taxonomic status is in need of revision.
Should be Allancastria (see Bollini and Racheli 2012).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear as the species is only known from the type specimen (C. Praz pers. comm. 2014).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear. It is considered conspecific with M. lefebvrei by some authors.
Ramme (1939) described this species as Rhacocleis silvestrii, named after Prof. F. Silvestri-Portici, but it is often cited as Rhacocleis sylvestrii.

The taxonomic status of this species is a matter of debate (Gorochov 2009, 2012). It may be a subspecies of Gryllomorpha dalmatina but this issue has not been definitely settled yet. The taxon was described as Gryllomorpha cretensis by Ramme (1927), however Eades et al. (2014) place the taxon as a subspecies of Gryllomorpha dalmatina Ramme, 1927. Gorochov and Ünal (2012) mentions G. cretensis in the context of G. dalmatina (p.54-55) but the text there states: "The first taxon [i.e. Gryllomorpha cretensis] is insufficiently studied, and its belonging to G. dalmatina is not evident; however, a single female from Crete I., recently studied by us, is similar to Ramme’s description and distinguished from the above-mentioned Turkish specimens as well as from the other Greek and Montenegro specimens by the smaller body size and transversally banded (not spotted) colouration of abdominal dorsum; this is probably a separate subspecies." In addition, the paper itself does not make the new combination. Although future studies may indeed prove this to be a subspecies of G. dalmatina, at present we retain G. cretensis as a species (L. Willemse pers. comm. 2015).
This species most probably represents a senior synonym of Demirsoyus salmani Sirin and Ciplak, 2004 in Yalim et al. (2004) (F. Willemse pers. comm. 2005).
The western subpopulation of this species needs to be compared with the eastern subpopulation to verify if they are conspecific.
This species is considered to possibly represent a local form of C. dorsalis by Willemse (1984). Taxonomic research is necessary to clarify the status of this species.
The taxonomic status of this species is still uncertain (Chobanov 2011) and needs further investigation.
The taxonomic status of Sphingonotus crivellarii is not clear. Whether it is indeed a distinct species or not still needs to be confirmed.

This species was described from the eastern Aegean island of Kos (Baccetti 1992). Baccetti described this species on the basis of the studies of Krimbas (1956a, 1956b, 1960), who found two Gryllotalpa species with different chromosome numbers in Greece. G. krimbasi has 19 chromosomes and Baccetti considered his specimen as typical for this form which was found by Krimbas in many places of the Greek mainland (see map 109a in Willemse 1984). Ingrisch et al. (2006) present further morphological details of krimbasi after material from Fthiotis, Central Greece, with a chromosome number of about 19

Acrometopa cretensis is a species with two subspecies: A. cretensis cretensis and A. cretensis daedali; see also the Orthoptera Species File (orthoptera.speciesfile.org/). This assessment is based on (distribution) data of the species.

Zeuner (1941) described Parnassiana tymphrestos from Mt.Timfristos (= Mt. Veluchi, compare Ramme, 1931). Ramme (1951) discussed the possible synonymy of P. tymphrestos and P. coracis but, not being aware that Mt. Korax is close to Mt. Timfristos, and by lack of material of P. tymphrestos, did not solve it, and the matter remains unsolved. For the time being, the material from Mt. Vardhousia recorded under P. tymphrestos in F. Willemse (1980 & 1984) should be transferred to Platycleis (Parnassiana) coracis Ramme, 1920. Likewise a re-evaluation of the population of Mt. Oiti, also arranged under P. tymphrestos in F. Willemse (1973 & 1980) appears necessary.

The identity of Rhacocleis agiostratica is not beyond doubt as the description has been based on juvenile specimens. Adult material is required to compare it with other Rhacocleis species in particular Rhacocleis distinguenda.
The genus Acrida is in need of taxonomic revision.

This species is often placed in the genus Anaciaeschna without any published evidence. The species appears distinct from both genera, but is retained in Aeshna until the issue is resolved (K.D. Djikstra pers. comm. 2018).
This species, formerly included in the genus Hemianax, is increasingly included in the genus Anax. As no genetic investigation is available, this remains controversial.
The Italian subspecies Poecilimon jonicus superbus is sometimes considered a unique species (Massa et al. 2012).

The species has long been considered as subspecies or even synonym of Eupholidoptera chabrieri (e.g. Ciplak et al. 2009). However, recent genetic evidence supports its species rank (Allegrucci et al. 2013).
This species is likely to be a synonym of Pholidoptera ebneri (Lemmonier-Darcemont et al. 2014).
The taxonomic status of Roeseliana ambitiosa is under debate. A taxonomic revision of the genus Roeseliana is needed (Chobanov and Mihajlova 2010).

Saga gracilis was considered a subspecies of S. campbelli for a long time, but currently it is treated as a separate species. Further taxonomic research is required to clarify its status (M. Lemonnier-Darcemont pers. comm. 2015).

A subspecies Orthetrum sabina viduatum Lieftinck, 1942, has been described from the highlands of central New Guinea. It is sometimes regarded as a synonym of O. sabina (Drury, 1773) (http://www.pugetsound.edu/academics/academic-resources/slater-museum/biodiversity-resources/dragonflies/world-odonata-list/). A genetic study of the species throughout its huge range is needed to understand its variability and possible subspeciation.
The species name is often misspelt as Diplacodes lefebvrei.
Subpopulations from Iraq and Kuwait have been ascribed to a poorly defined subspecies, Orthetrum trinacria igarashii Asahina, 1973. Its taxonomic status needs clarification.

Libellula haematina Rambur, 1842, described from Senegal and Madagascar, and claimed to be occurring in La Réunion, Mauritius and Sicily, represents the infraspecific variability and cannot be accepted as a valid taxon despite the treatment published by Ris (1912).
Trithemis jacksoni is a synonym (Dijkstra unpubl.).
Sympetrum nigrifemur (from the Canaries and Madeira) is considered a subspecies of S. striolatum.

Until 2004, Erythromma lindenii was placed in the genus Cercion although Heidemann and Seidenbusch (1993) had already suggested that the species should be placed in Erythromma based on larval characters. It was not until Weekers and Dumont (2004) confirmed this idea with a DNA-study that this was widely accepted.
Sometimes the subspecies kocheri is recognised.

This species was formerly considered a subspecies of Saga campbelli by Kaltenbach (1967) and it was later established as a distinct species based on genetic markers by Kolics et al.(2012). According to M. Lemonnier-Darcemont pers. comm. 2015, there is proof of the synonymy between S. gracilis and S. campbelli.

Alosterna pauli Pesarini, Rapuzzi & Sabbadini, 2004 was described in the group of species related to A. anatolica Adlbauer, 1992 and A. tabacicolor (De Geer, 1775) (Adlbauer 1992, Pesarini and Sabbadini 2004). It differs from them on the basis of strong elements while the description paper gives precise drawings. Some mistakes remain in the documentation, like in Fauna Europaea where the description date is 2003 (De Jong et al. 2014) or wrong bibliographic reference for the description (Tavakilian and Chevillotte 2012).

Fabricius’ Entomologia systematica dedicated to Cerambycidae (first tome), was published in two parts with the date 1792 indicated on the title page of the first part. The second part was published in 1793 (Gaedike et al. 2012), not in 1792 as listed by authors. The correct name is Pidonia lurida (Fabricius, 1793: 343) (Danilevsky 2016).

Xylosteus caucasicola Plavilstshikov, 1936 is considered by Sama and Rapuzzi (1999), Sama (2002), and Löbl and Smetana (2010), as a subspecies of X. spinolae, while according to Miroshnikov (1998, pers. comm. 2016), and to Danilevsky (2016) this taxonomic transfer is unacceptable. Based on the review of dozens of specimens, Miroshnikov (1998) showed clear distinctive characters between the two taxa and confirmed the specific status of X. caucasicola. Sama and Rapuzzi (1999) replied that not enough specimens have been studied, especially specimens from south-eastern Europe that are viewed as transitional forms between spinolae and caucasicola. Here, X. caucasicola is considered as a good species, endemic to the Caucasus and the Krasnodar mountains. In Turkey, Miroshnikov (2000), described X. kadleci that could be a subspecies of X. caucasicola but more specimens are needed from Anatolia to confirm this hypothesis.

Corticeus krueperi is only known by the type specimen and recorded only from Greece, without any locality (Obenberger 1922). It has not been recorded since and the type specimen hasn't been examined. This species could be a synonym of another European Corticeus species or could correspond to a foreign species due to mislabelling.

Corticeus rufithorax is probably a very rare Mediterranean form of Corticeus linearis. Described from Greece, without precision, the species has been recorded in the Balearic Islands. Among specimens of C. linearis living on Pinus halepensis collected in the French Mediterranean  and in Spain, some specimens could correspond to Corticeus rufithorax, and there seem to be intermediate specimens between both taxa in Spain (Espanol 1967). 

In spite of this, C. rufithorax Pic, 1903 has not been officially put in synonymy with C. linearis, including type examination and is considered as a valid species in Löbl et al. (2008), and we retain C. rufithorax as a valid species (F. Soldati, pers. comm. 2015).

In 1985, Sláma described Brachyleptura martini from Crete. However, the name was preoccupied by Leptura semirufula var. martini (Pic, 1945) described from Madrid, and thereafter synonym of Stictoleptura trisignata (Fairmaire, 1852). So, when Brachyleptura was included in the new genus Stictoleptura, the species of Sláma was changed to S. slamai Sama, 2010.

Leptorhabdium illyricum was described by Kraatz in 1871 based on specimens coming from the central Balkans, without precise localities. For a long time, the species remained mysterious and hidden since the literature only discussed taxonomy, without adding information about localities or biology. In 1986, Ohbayashi and Shimomura gave precise drawings for all those species. Then, Sama (1993) confirmed taxonomical choices after a study of the type specimens in Pic and Kraatz's collections. Therefore, he fixed the taxonomy among the European Leptorhabdium-Xylosteus group. That taxonomy is followed here.
Placed within the subgenus Petrochilosina. The species name was erroneously spelled 'octhoniai' in the title, abstract and discussion of the describing paper (Alexiou et al. 2015).

Astacus leptodactylus is referred to as a species complex. In the 1950s this species was believed to belong to the subgenus Astacus (Potastacus) along with A. (P.) pachypus, A. (P.) pylzowi and A. (P.) kessleri.The following four subspecies were attributed to A. (P.) leptodactylus: eichwaldi, cubanicus, salinus, and leptodactylus. Karaman (1962, 1963) however does not acknowledge A. (P.) cubanicus as a subspecies. In the 1970s, Pontastacus was raised to generic level. In the 1980s, Brodskij made a number of revisions within Pontastacus but the number of taxa varied within papers. In the mid 1990s Starobogatov (1995) split Pontastacus into two genera: Pontastacus - P. angulosus (Rathke, 1837); P. cubanicus (Birstein & Winogradow, 1934); P. danubialis (Brodskij, 1967); P. eichwaldi (Bott, 1950); P. intermedius (Bott, 1950); P. kessleri (Schimkewitsch, 1886); P. pyzlowi (Skorikov, 1911); P. salinus (Nordmann, 1942), and Caspiastacus with two species. However, there is great deal of criticism over the recent revision in taxonomy made by Ukranian and Russian taxonomists as it appears to be based on little evidence.
In line with a new publication: Crandall, K.A. & S. De Grave. (2017). An updated classification of the freshwater crayfishes (Decapoda: Astacidea) of the world, with a complete species list. Journal of Crustacean Biology. This species formally under the genus Astacus has been moved to Pontastacus.
Three subspecies are known: Austropotamobius torrentium torrentium, A. t. danubicus, and A. t. macedonicus.

In Europe, there are many different subspecies, forms and aberrations noted for this species, presumably because of the very divided nature of the distribution area and as a consequence, large isolation of populations. Separated by mountains, the populations develop independently of one another, so that quite marked differences arise. However, it has been argued that “colour and pattern variation, including polymorphism, is quite common in butterflies, and its taxonomic value has been severely disputed, as it may, at least in part, result from phenotypic plasticity” (Todisco et al. 2010). The same paper highlights that in several instances, populations from different subspecies share similar or identical mtDNA, so have either recently diverged or are not different from one another (Todisco et al. 2010).

Formerly, Boyeria cretensis was confused with—and regarded as a subpopulation of—Boyeria irene (Fonscolombe, 1838), but both species are clearly distinct (Boudot 1989, Peters 1991, Kohli et al. 2014).

A number of subspecies and forms have been described in the Calopteryx splendens group. Their validity is sometimes doubtful and the overall systematics and genetics of these taxa are far from being elucidated, although genetic research is currently developing rapidly. For these reasons, C. splendens will be assessed here as a collective taxon.

Until recently Ceragrion georgiferyi was considered a subspecies of Ceriagrion tenellum, but both male and female show distinct morphological characters and it is now considered to be a full species (Schneider 1986, Kalkman 2005).

A number of subspecies of Ischnura elegans have been described, of which only the widely accepted I. e. elegans (Vander Linden, 1820), I. e. ebneri Schmidt, 1938 and I. e. pontica Schmidt, 1938 are recognised in this assessment; all are treated together here.

Until recently this species was regarded as subspecies of Pyrrhosoma nymphula. Kalkman and Lopau (2006) illustrated the differences between the two taxa and confirmed that they should be treated as two full valid species.

There have been speculations about Sicilian populations being a distinct subspecies, Cordulegaster bidentata sicilica Fraser, 1929. However, more recent genetic studies found no evidence to support the validity of this subspecies (Froufe et al. 2014, Boudot and Holusa 2015). Still, the overall systematic organisation of the various members of this taxon remains unclear (Boudot 2001, Boudot et al. 2009).

Three subspecies have been described: Cordulegaster helladica helladica, C. h. buchholzi and C. h. kastalia, but the separation between them remains very difficult and even intermediate forms between those subspecies have been described.

The two subspecies described: Cordulegaster heros heros Theischinger, 1979 and Cordulegaster heros pelionensis Theischinger, 1979. These subspecies differ only by the shape or the lack of the black band on the frons in male imagoes, and are not assessed separately for the Red List.

The Easternmost populations in the Russian Far East and Japan are sometimes regarded as a distinct subspecies (Cordulia aenea amurensis), but as no definite range can be ascribed to these populations, which are poorly differentiated, this is not consensually accepted (J.-P. Boudot, pers. comm.)

Ophiogomphus obscurus, O. spnicornis and O. reductus were formerly considered as subspecies of O. cecilia. Presently these Asian taxa are regarded as full species and as they do not occur in Europe, this discussion has no influence on the European regional assessment.

The species is currently split into two subspecies: Orthetrum coerulescens anceps (located in northern Africa, Sardinia, the southern Balkans and parts of Asia) and O. c. coerulescens. Intermediate forms occur in Iberia, Sicily and large parts of south-eastern Europe (Dijkstra and Lewington 2006).

Mauersberger (1994) suggests that O. coerulescens and O. anceps are not full species but either members of a superspecies or even subspecies which would have to be united under the older name Orthetrum coerulescens (Fabricius). The species overlaps with Orthetrum coerulescens, in Europe and hybrids have been recorded.

Parts of the Balkan populations are refered to the subspecies Platycnemis pennipes nitidula (Brullé 1832). It has a very narrow range and seems to hybridize with the nominotypical subspecies so that its precise range is still unclear. Both taxa are assessed together here, although some people regard them as distinct species due to their structural differences.

The species belongs to Eumerus olivaceus group. E. alpinus Rondani, 1857 was resurrected from synonymy of E. olivaceus Loew, 1848 and considered a good species by Grković et al. (2015). Until than the name of E. olivaceus was used for both species.

Vujić et al. (2013) successfully used an integrative taxonomy approach for delimitation of Pipiza noctiluca from related species. P. noctiluca can be separated from related species using molecular data and geometric morphometric evidence: wing size and shape (Vujić et al. 2013).

Vujić et al. (2008) provide figures of the male terminalia and the key distinguishing Pipiza luteibarba from other European members of the luteitarsis group. The luteitarsis group of species may be distinguished from other European Pipiza by the lack of apicoventral ridges on the hind femora. P. luteibarba can be separated from other European species of the genus using the key provided by Vujić et al. (2013).

Pipiza laurusi cannot be separated using traditional morphological characters, only with molecular data and using geometric morphometric evidence: wing size and shape (Vujić et al. 2013). Distribution can also be used to separate this species from Pipiza lugubris.
Pipiza austriaca can be separated from other European species of genus using key from Vujić et al. (2013)

This newly-recognized European monotypic genus has been discovered and described recently (Vujić et al. 2019). The systematic position of the taxon is within the tribe Rhingiini. Katara connexa is shiny, black species with broad, oval abdomen, which is distinctly broader than thorax in both sexes. Eyes are separated in both sexes (Vujić et al. 2019).

Cheilosia redi belongs to the nominal subgenus. It was originally described (Vujic 1996) as a subspecies of Cheilosia melanopa, it was raised to species level by Francuski et al. (2009), on the results of a comparative morphometric study of the adult insects involving C. lasiopa, C. melanopa and C. variabilis (Speight 2018).

A species of the subgenus Taeniocheilosia. For identification see key to males of European Taeniocheilosia (as Nigrocheilosia) species in StN Keys volume; and Barkalov and Ståhls (1997) who figure the male terminalia.

Cheilosia psilophthalma belongs to the nominate subgenus. In some recent keys this species would usually key out to C. urbana, since C.psilophthalma can have antennae that are from pale orange to almost black, and the keys do not accommodate this range of variation. This species can also be confused with C. latigenis (Speight 2018).

Cheilosia pascorum belongs to proxima group of species of nominal subgenus. For identification see key of European species of proxima group in Vujić et al. (2013) who figure the male terminalia. In general appearance C. pascuorum closely resembles C. gigantea, but has abdominal tergites that are entirely pale (yellow-brown) haired, whereas in C. gigantea black hairs are also present. Where it meets R4+5, vein M1 is curved slightly toward the wing base in C. pascuorum. In the other species it either meets R4+5 at a right angle or is pointing more toward the wing apex, in consequence reaching R4+5 at an angle less than 90° (Speight 2018).
Cheilosia lenta belongs to the nominate subgenus. It is extremely difficult to separate C. lenta from C. rhynchops. The main difference is absence of pilosity at mid of katepisternum.

Cheilosia laeviseta is a species of the subgenus Taeniocheilosia. For identification see the key to males of European Taeniocheilosia (as Nigrocheilosia) species in StN Keys volume; and Barkalov and Ståhls (1997) who figured the male terminalia.
Cheilosia katara belongs to nominal subgenus Cheilosia. An identification key distinguishing C. katara from other related species was provided by Vujić and Claussen (2000).

Cheilosia himantopa belongs to canicularis species group of the subgenus Cheilosia. From the closely similar Cheilosia canicularis it can be distinguished based on features published by Stuke and Claussen (2000).

Cheilosia cynocephala is a member of the nominal subgenus. C.cynocephala is more variable in size than many other Cheilosia species, from the dimensions of C.melanura down to those of C. vernalis. Distinction of the males from C.melanura and C.vernalis on any basis other than the blue-black colour of C.cynocephala can be difficult. The surstyli of the male terminalia are figured by Stubbs and Falk (2002). Falk (2004) discusses the differences between males of spring and summer populations of C. cynocephala in Britain and how they may be distinguished from C. vernalis.

Cheilosia antiqua belongs to the subgenus Taeniochilosia. The species is morphologically similar to Cheilosia nigripes, and identification keys are provided by Barkalov and Ståhls (1997), and StN keys in Speight (2020).

Until recently (e.g. Peck 1988), Claussenia hispanica has been regarded as a synonym of Heringia heringi (Zetterstedt). It may be found in flight with H. heringi and the two species are virtually indistinguishable in the field, though males of C. hispanica are usually slightly larger than those of H. heringi (Speight 2018). A key distinguishing these two species is provided by Speight and Sarthou (2017). One of the features used to characterise C. hispanica is the presence of hairs at the ventral extremity of the median lobe of the lunule. These can be absent in the female (Speight 2018). Claussen et al. (1994) figured the male terminalia.

Records of this species from Anatolia (Turkey) require confirmation; they probably refer to Pipizella orientalis (van Steenis and Lucas 2011), and P. annulata is considered to be endemic to Europe here.

Two different taxa are clearly encompassed by the names Cheilosia morio and C. scanica, but correct application of these names and consequently relative range limits remain to be established (Speight 2020). The identities of Cheilosia morio (Zetterstedt 1838) (Syrphidae, tribe Rhingiini) and of its synonyms are reviewed by Doczkal and Claußen (in prep.). This work referred Cheilosia scanica Ringdahl, 1937 to the synonymy of Cheilosia morio (Zetterstedt, 1838) and determined that the name C. morio had been widely misapplied to a distinct species, for which these authors resurrected the name Cheilosia luteicornis (Zetterstedt, 1838). This nomenclature was used in a few recent publications (Nilsson et al. 2012, van Steenis 2016).

Cheilosia morio belongs to the subgenus Neocheilosia. From the most similar species it can be distinguished by its smaller size, presence of black pile around facial knob and black pile on terga. In Bartsch et al. (2009) this species is mentioned as Cheilosia morio B.

The identity of Callicera rohdendorfi Zimina, 1982 with respect to C. macquarti requires confirmation. Zimina (1986) described details of Callicera rohdendorfi which led to the assumption that it should be C. macquarti. Callicera rohdendorfi was considered to be "almost certainly the same" as C. macquarti by Speight (1991), however this requires confirmation based on review of the Zimina holotype and/or paratype specimens of Callicera rohdendorfi. If C. rohdendorfi is a synonym of C. macquarti, then the range of C. macquarti extends to Crimea and the Caucasus, probably to Azerbaijan.

Callicera macquarti is probably synonymous with C. fagesii according to recent results from DNA analysis, but Callicera macquarti is maintained as a valid species until its identity is formally revised.
A recent record (Mutin and Barkalov 2018) of this species from Omsk (Siberia) refer to another species, with genetic confirmation (A. Grković pers. comm. 2021).

Cheilosia thessala belongs to the longula species group closely resembling the species Cheilosia scutellata. Claussen and Ståhls (2007) provided the key to separate this species from others in the C. scutellata group and also figured the male terminalia (Speight 2018).

Cheilosia semifasciata is a small species with hairy eyes and dark legs with at least the apical ends of all femora and/or the base of all tibiae yellow in both sexes. High altitude specimens may have entirely black legs (Schmid 2000). It is the most similar with C. rhodiolae Schmid, 2000. To separate these two species from one another it is necessary to refer Schmid (2000). The surstyli of the male terminalia are figured out by Stubbs and Falk (2002).

Vujić et al. (2013) successfully used an integrative taxonomy approach for delimitation of Pipiza notata from related species. P. notata can be separated from related species using subtle characters in male genitalia, molecular data and geometric morphometric evidence: wing size and shape (Vujić et al. 2013).
The species is morphologically similar to Palumbia eristaloides (Portschinsky, 1887), and further research is needed to determine whether they may be the same taxon.

authority: J. van Steenis and W. van Steenis, 2014

taxonomicNotes: There is uncertainty as to which genus Epistrophella coronata should be referred to because the only other species of this genus - E. euchroma - is consigned by some authors to the genus Meligramma (Speight 2020).

This species can be found in literature under the genera Melanostoma and Meligramma. It resembles Melanostoma species but it can be separate from them by the abdominal markings, which widen progressively towards the lateral margins of the tergites, meeting the lateral margins at full width. In addition, the second tergite bears a pair of narrow, transverse, whitish yellow bars, which come to a point towards the mid-line, while tergites three and four each exhibit either a pair of bars or a narrow, transverse band, of the same colour as the markings on tergite two (Speight 2020).

This species is recently described (2001) and might need genetic verification to confirm that it is a separate species. It is very close to Anasimyia transfuga which is a widespread species but has not been found in the same locality as Anasimyia femorata (Speight 2020).
Some differences with the male genitalia showed in different publications suggest more than one species might be included inside Psilota anthracina (Speight 2020).
Pelopidas thrax ssp. inconspicua (Bertoloni, 1850) was synonymized with P. thrax (Hübner, [1821]) by Larsen (2005).
We follow e.g. LepIndex (Beccaloni et al. 2021) and Wiemers et al. (2018) in placing this species in the genus Freyeria, but in Williams (2020) it is retained in genus Chilades.
This species was included in the subgenus Stereosa Casey, 1909 (Verdugo 2005) but more recently, it was changed to the subgenus Cypriacis Casey, 1909 (Kubán 2006).
Schneider et al. (2018) regard the taxa Gomphus amseli and G. schneiderii transcaspicus as synonyms of G. schneiderii.
Initially described as Parablops aetnensis.
This species needs to be taxonomically studied due to uncertainty of its relationships with Pholidoptera rhodopensis and the possible synonymy of both taxa.
The species is very close to P. globulicollis and its status (valid species or subspecies of P. globulicollis) is unclear, pending molecular data (Rapuzzi and Sama 2013).

There are old records of this species which are now thought to be related to R.ungaricus. According to Sama (2002) the whole genus is problematic from a nomenclatural point of view since all type specimens are lost. A taxonomic revision is necessary.
This species is considered a subspecies of Cordulegaster helladica, but given the closeness of the two taxa, genetic investigations are in work to provide new taxonomic information.
In addition to the nominotypical one, two subspecies have been described, namely C. h. buchholzi (Lohmann, 1993) and C. h. kastalia (Lohmann, 1993).
This species is considered a subspecies of Cordulegaster helladica but genetic investigations are in work to get new informations about the systematic position of the various members of C. helladica.

Cheilosia candida Vujić et Radenković, 2020 is a member of the subgenus Convocheila Barkalov, and endemic to Europe. The species was described based on a single male specimen. Radenković et al. (2020) provide images of the male, including the male genitalia, and an identification key to separate the species from all other members of subgenus Convocheila. The species is morphologically similar to C. paralobi Malski, and distinguishing characters are provided in Radenković et al. (2020).
The taxonomy of this species has to be reviewed in the T. baudueri complex (H. Brustel pers. comm. 2015).
This Grayling used to be considered a subspecies of Brown's Grayling, or Buff's Asian Grayling (P. mamurra), which occurs in the Asian part of Turkey.

In addition to the nominotypical subspecies, this taxon includes subspecies Calopteryx virgo ssp. meridionalis Selys, 1873 from the southwestern Mediterranean (Iberia and most southern part of France)) and Calopteryx virgo ssp. festiva (Brullé, 1832) in southeastern Europe (from Slovenia to Greece). The nominotypical subspecies occurs throughout most of Europe.

Calopteryx japonica Selys, 1869 occurs in the eastern part of the Palearctic region, this taxon was for a long time considered to be a subspecies of C. virgo. As a result, the range of these two species in parts of Asia is still unclear. C. japonica occurs east of Lake Baikal, whilst west of the Ural Mountains occurs C. virgo, but the border between them in western Siberia is unclear.
